abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Water Resource
            Management Project for Albania were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was substantial, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Lessons learned include: costing of project
            activities should be based on updated data and targets at
            appraisal should be based on realistic estimates and not on
            inaccurate budgets. More comprehensive approach should have
            been used in improving dam safety including more detailed
            geotechnical and hydrological investigations to determine
            the characteristics of the dams and their resistance to
            earthquakes which can reduce the risk of dam failure
            substantially. Adequate capacity should be developed and
            maintained in the Ministry of Agriculture, Food, and
            Consumer Protection (MOAFCP) to deal with dam safety issues
            of the large number irrigation dams. Dam safety problems
            were identified during the inventory study but the effort
            can be lost if there is poor capacity and/or commitment for
            action. Similarly, the MOAFCP capacity for supervision of
            civil works should be formally included in the Ministry
            structure and proper training should be provided to the
            unit. Also, incentives should be considered to enable the
            experts to carry out their work beyond the regular working
            hours to respond to the project needs. The cost of
            contracted supervision services should be based on
            competitive basis and not on the fixed regulation of the
            Government that ignores the required work involved. The
            transfer of Project Management Unit (PMU) staff and its
            functions during implementation to the line ministry to
            create capacity can also fail if there is not a strong
            commitment to make it work. The transfer had to be reversed
            in the case of supervision of works. Importance of having
            the legal framework for irrigation institutions that clearly
            defines duties and responsibilities to ensure Water Users
            Association (WUO) sustainability.

5146500.trustfund:
TF052419-PHRD-ALBANIA: THIRD IRRIGATION
            AND DRAINAGE REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF030477-GERMAN CTF FY04 - ENVIRONMENT
            & PUBLIC SECTOR MANAGEMENT
5146500.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Environment and natural resource management,Rural development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Albania Water Resources Management
            Project aims to: (a) increase agricultural production, (b)
            increase the financial viability o f irrigation and drainage
            schemes, and (c) reduce the risk o f dam failures and
            floods. In addition, the project aims at achieving the
            interim (output) objective o f contributing to the first
            step towards the development o f comprehensive water
            resource management. There are five project components.
            Component 1 supports system repair and comprises the
            following subcomponents: 1) repair and improvement of
            irrigation facilities; 2) repair and improvement of flood
            control and drainage facilities; 3) repair of irrigation
            reservoirs and dams; 4) design and supervision;5)
            implementation of the environmental management plan, which
            consists of a training program introducing best practices
            and environmental monitoring for sub-projects; and 6)
            development of an investment program for phases 2 and 3.
            Component 2 finances  institutional support for irrigation,
            drainage and flood management sector. Its subcomponents
            establish water users associations and a federation (FWUAs),
            and provide them training and technical support;
            institutional support for drainage boards; and support to
            the Department of Water Management in the agricultural
            ministry. Component 3 funds institutional support for water
            resource management by improving the legal and institutional
            framework, assessing flood-prone areas, preparing a dam
            safety program, and supporting river basin administration,
            hydrometric network and water quality measurement , and the
            technical secretariat. Component 4 finances project
            management and component 5 repays the Project Preparation Facility.

3492775.trustfund:
TF030477-GERMAN CTF FY04 - ENVIRONMENT

repnme.cdata!:
Albania - Water Resources Management
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment for
            the Water Resources Management Project, which helps Albania
            increase the contribution of water resources for
            agricultural production. The irrigation schemes comprising
            this project are environmentally acceptable with negative
            impacts either nil or minor. This report discusses  likely
            these negative social and environmental impacts and the
            measures proposed to mitigate them, which generally consist
            of engineering interventions incorporated into the design of
            the scheme, or modifications to farming practices (through
            training schemes) to reduce groundwater and drain pollution
            by agrochemicals. Potential negative impacts caused by the
            rehabilitation works during construction include
            disturbance, noise, and dust, and disposal problems. It is
            proposed to program work to minimize disruption during
            sowing and harvesting, avoid cultivated areas, and monitor
            construction activities. Also, these impacts are temporary
            and will cease when the works are completed. During the
            operational phase, potential environmental impacts may arise
            from sediment accumulation in canals, deterioration of water
            quality downstream and groundwater sources, disturbance to
            localized ecosystems, and hydrological disturbance (the
            latter is not expected in any of the six schemes).
            Mitigations include regularly inspecting and clearing
            canals, deep ploughing, using water efficiently, maintaining
            drains, monitoring groundwater levels and salinity,
            restricting nitrogen application on fields, providing health
            awareness to farmers, well water sampling (for nitrates,
            phosphates, and F. coliform bacteria), managing the
            watershed, and using river training works and inspecting and
            reporting riverbank erosion.
